newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch soccer death looked like "seal cull" -wiitness.
newsitem.headline: Dutch soccer death looked like "seal cull" -wiitness.

text.p: The Dutch soccer gang leader slain in a pre-arranged battle on Sunday was surrounded and clubbed to death by nearly 20 fans from a rival club, a witness told Dutch television on Monday.
"They clubbed him like it was some sort of seal cull," said the young man with close-cropped hair whose identity was concealed in the television report.
Gangs of Ajax Amsterdam and Feyenoord Rotterdam fans met and fought with knives and baseball bats on waste ground by a motorway 20 miles from Amsterdam on Sunday.
Carlo Picornie, who died surrounded by at least 18 Feyenoord fans, was well-known as a ringleader of an ultra-hard faction in Ajax's fanatical "F-Side" supporters gang, Dutch newspapers reported.
He was 35, had a girlfriend and two small children and owned a hotel in central Amsterdam.
"He made a terrible mistake yesterday, one of his friends told a local newspaper. "They called him out and Carlo went. A few of the old Feyenoorders must have known him very well."
His death was the first caused by the hooliganism that has blighted Dutch soccer for more than 20 years.
Dozens of police spent Monday scouring the field where the gangs fought. Others questioned motorists who might have passed near the scene.
Twenty-eight people were arrested after the fight and police said they were scanning a video from a motorway surveillance camera hoping to identify the rioters.
The suspects were being held in police stations around the Kennemerland region west of Amsterdam. Police in Rotterdam and Amsterdam were also helping the investigation.

Ringleaders marshalled armed hooligans to the wasteground -- miles away from either team's ground on a day when their teams were not playing each other -- using mobile phones to outwit police attempts to keep them apart.
Chief superintendent Cees Bakker of the Netherlands' senior police officers' committee told television he feared the clash could herald further violence as gang members sought revenge.
"I'm extremely concerned that this could be the start of a series of such incidents," he said.
"It has all the hallmarks of a gang war situation and we must be careful that we can free up more capacity to head off further such incidents," Bakker said.
Another senior policeman called for more extensive use of helicopters to follow aggressive football fans.

Justice Minister Winnie Sorgdrager and Home Affairs Minister Hans Dijkstal laid the groundwork for meetings with sporting and police bodies to discuss football violence, the Justice Ministry said on Monday.

"These are gangs of hardened criminals, groups who seek each other out to fight," Dijkstal said, calling for tougher sentences. "This is hard work for the police and judiciary. We must track down these groups and punish them."
